newsitem.title: GERMANY: Reynolds sees rising aluminium uses.
newsitem.headline: Reynolds sees rising aluminium uses.

text.p: Reynolds Metals Co, the U.S. producer and fabricator, saw rising aluminium uses in transport, packaging and building, vice president William Gray Reynolds said on Tuesday.
"Per-capita consumption growth of aluminium is set to accelerate and we intend to supply it," Reynolds said at a luncheon organised by the American Chamber of Commerce in Germany.
Per-capita consumption of 60 lb per year in the U.S. compared with just seven lb in Asia, Russia and Africa.
Expansion in these markets would be "risky, but worth it," said Reynolds, who is in charge of press and intergovernmental relations.
Global aluminium consumption in vehicles could rise to six million tonnes by the year 2000 from currently 3.7 million tonnes, he predicted.
Engineering requirements of light weight, value-added materials coincided with consumer demands for quality and safety, which would benefit aluminium, he said.
While transport may overtake packaging as the key application, there was also huge growth potential in Eastern European, Middle Eastern and Latin American beverage can markets.
Reynolds said production in the global can sheet market would expand rapidly as new operations were due to come on stream in a number of countries, including Reynolds plants in Argentina and Chile.
The company was also working on framing systems for prefabricated aluminium houses, mostly for overseas markets, and on new residential building products.
